production.title: Production
production.content:
According to a report from PLASTICS|SA (2021), which represents {{country}}s plastic industry, the country meets a significant share of its domestic plastic demand with locally produced ethylene. However, production of polyethene grades (LDPE, LLDPE and HDPE) does not fully meet local demand, while polypropylene (PP) capacity exceeds domestic requirements, resulting in substantial exports. Despite this, {{country}} continues to import polyolefin polymers to access specific grades not produced locally, to manage seasonal shortages, and to diversify supply.

{{country}} remains a net importer of polymers and plastic products, despite having two major polymer producers. In 2021, the plastics trade deficit reportedly reached ZAR 20.5 billion (USD 1.43 billion), representing a 25% deficit relative to an estimated domestic industry value of ZAR 83.2 billion (USD 5.8 billion).

trade.title: Trade
keyTrends: Between 2017 and 2022, {{country}} imported approximately USD 29 billion in plastics and related products, reflecting strong, growing domestic demand.
Plastic imports are dominated by primary polymers and finished goods, highlighting dependence on imported resin feedstocks and consumer products.
{{country}} exported approximately USD 13 billion in plastics over the same period, primarily commodity polymers and converted products, such as packaging and pipes.
Synthetic textiles, footwear, and rubber products account for a large share of plastic-related imports, indicating limited domestic scale competitiveness in high-volume consumer and industrial goods.

Trade patterns place {{country}} in a midstream position in the plastics value chain: active in polymer trade and conversion but not self-sufficient across resin types or competitive in speciality plastics.
trade.summaryLeft:
Plastic Imports

A total of 28,550 million USD worth of plastic was imported to {{country}} between 2017-2022. In the latest reporting year 2022, the total imports reached value of 5,578 million USD, of which:

  • ~ 35% was plastic in primary forms
  • ~ 14% was plastic in intermediate forms
  • ~ 11% was intermediate manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 40% was final manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 0% was plastic waste.

The plastic imports included estimated 695 million USD of plastic packaging imports with notoriously short product lifetime.

Plastic exports

A total of 12,983 million USD worth of plastic was exported from {{country}} in the year(s) 2017-2022. In the latest reporting year 2022, exports reached a value of USD 2,507 million, of which:

  • ~ 37% was plastic in primary forms
  • ~ 9% was plastic in intermediate forms
  • ~ 9% was intermediate manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 45% was final manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 0% was plastic waste.

Plastic exports included estimated 348 million USD of plastic packaging.
trade.summary:
Plastic trade trends

Between years 2017 and 2022, the amount of plastic imported to {{country}} has increased by 25.1%, while the amount of plastic exported from {{country}} has increased by 22.2%.

Imports of plastics in primary forms rose by 46%, intermediate materials by 11%, intermediate goods by 15%, and final goods by 19%. Plastic waste imports increased sharply by 133%, while exports of plastic waste fell by 70% over the same period.

Overall, the data suggests that the plastics sector is expanding across the value chain in {{country}}, is highly dependent on imports (especially for raw materials), and is increasing domestic consumption of plastic products. Increasing waste exports indicate growing challenges in managing plastic waste.
trade.tradingPartners: {{country}}s plastics trade reflects its value chain position: it imports predominantly from Asia (to a lesser extent, Europe and the Americas), including specialised raw and intermediate inputs that are not produced locally, as well as significant volumes of finished and semi-finished plastic goods. {{country}} exports primarily to African markets, supplying locally produced polymers and manufactured products. This indicates that {{country}} is both a regional producer-exporter and a net importer of higher-value or specialised plastics rather than a simple import-convert-export model.
trade.productCategories: The World Trade Organisations database can provide more in-depth insights into specific products. This HS-based plastics trade structure indicates that {{country}} is positioned upstream and in the midstream of the plastics value chain. The largest import and export items are plastics and articles thereof (HS Chapter 39), specifically primary polymers, indicating that {{country}} is active in polymer production and trade but not self-sufficient across the resin spectrum. {{country}} also imports a large volume of semi-finished plastic products, such as films, sheets, and reinforced plastics, accounting for several hundred million USD. Exports are led by commodity polymers (notably propylene and ethylene resins) mainly for the African market, followed by basic plastic articles such as packaging, pipes, and general-purpose plastic goods. Rubber and articles thereof (HS Chapter 40) indicates that domestic demand for rubber is driven by the automotive, mining, industrial, and infrastructure sectors. Rubber exports are far more concentrated and downstream-oriented, led overwhelmingly by new pneumatic tyres, followed by industrial rubber goods such as conveyor belts, hoses, and general vulcanised articles.

consumption.title: Consumption
consumption.content:
National plastic consumption is reported at 1.53.2 million tonnes per year between 2017 and 2022, driven primarily by packaging, textiles, consumer goods, construction materials, and automotive applications.

Plastic consumption is calculated as total imports minus exports, using UNCTAD data. {{country}}s net plastic trade increased from 2.4 to 3.0 billion USD between 2017 and 2022. After a dip in 2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic, consumption rebounded strongly.

According to a report from PLASTICS|SA (2021), which represents {{country}}s plastic industry, {{country}} converted approximately 2 million tons of polymer into plastics product. This is the total of locally produced polymers, imported polymers and recycled polymers sold to local converters in {{country}}, virgin and recycled. The top manufactured product by plastic converters in {{country}} is packaging (50%), followed by building and construction (14%).

wasteManagement.title: Waste Management
keyTrends: Between 2017 and 2020, {{country}} generated approximately 1.52.6 million tonnes of plastic waste annually.
Plastic waste collection coverage is relatively high, with an estimated 6585% collected nationally, though performance varies widely between metropolitan and non-metropolitan municipalities.

Approximately 1528% of plastic waste is formally recovered (300,000360,000 tonnes per year), with informal waste pickers playing a critical role in recycling, though they remain unevenly integrated into formal systems.
Open dumping and open burning of plastic waste persist, particularly in areas with weaker collection and treatment infrastructure, contributing to environmental leakage and health risks.
wasteManagement.content:
Plastic waste from municipal solid waste

An estimated 12,453 thousand tonnes of municipal solid waste were generated in {{country}} in 2020. Plastic waste generation estimates from various studies range from 1.5 to 2.6 million tonnes per year, equivalent to roughly 2345 kg per capita, depending on the estimate methodology and year.

A study on global waste management modelling showed 85% of municipal solid waste is collection coverage, while another study estimated 6585% of plastic waste from municipal solid waste collected (approximately 1.12.2 million tonnes per year). It should be noted that waste collection varies significantly by municipality, with metropolitan areas achieving high coverage and smaller or rural municipalities lagging behind. As a result, a large amount of plastic waste remains uncollected or improperly managed each year, contributing to leakage into terrestrial and aquatic environments.

An estimated 37.8% of municipal solid waste is managed in controlled facilities. Model-based estimates suggest that, on the order of hundreds of thousands of tonnes per year of mismanaged plastic waste in {{country}} may be disposed of through open burning, depending on the assumptions used. A study on global waste management modelling estimated that annual plastic emission, including both debris and open burning, is 609,757 tonnes per year, which is equivalent to 10 kg/person/year.

{{country}} has one of the largest and most developed plastic recycling sectors in Africa, recycling approximately 300,000350,000 tonnes per year between 2017 and 2020, equivalent to 1528% of plastic waste generated, depending on the source and year.
wasteManagement.contentRight:
Plastic waste from non-municipal solid waste

There is no data on plastic waste flows and leakages from the non-municipal solid waste stream.

environment.title: Plastics in the Environment
keyTrends: Plastic dominates marine litter on {{country}}s beaches, accounting for approximately 95% of all recorded litter items, with single-use beverage containers (especially PET bottles) the most common items.

Both local land-based sources and offshore inputs are significant, but their relative importance varies strongly by location: local sources dominate urban beaches, while offshore sources dominate remote beaches.

Illegal dumping from ships and long-distance drift from Southeast Asia are major contributors to the presence of foreign plastic items on {{country}}s shores, underscoring that marine litter is both a national and transboundary issue.
Beach cleaning reduces visible litter but does not address root causes, as plastics continue to enter the marine environment at scale.
environment.content:
Beach litter

Beach litter study compiling data from 32 sites between June 2019 and September 2020 shows strong spatial gradients linked to proximity to urban centres. Beaches near cities are dominated by {{country}}-manufactured plastics, reflecting local leakage from inadequate containment, stormwater runoff, rivers, and coastal use.

However, even well-managed urban beaches receive episodic inputs during rainfall events and coastal upwelling, which remobilise litter already in the marine environment. Bottle densities vary widely, ranging from fewer than 10 to more than 400 bottles per kilometre, with urban beaches experiencing high but variable inputs and remote beaches accumulating larger standing stocks due to limited or absent cleaning.

Common plastic items in the environment

Plastic drink bottles dominate environmental litter, accounting for more than two-thirds of all recorded items, with PET bottles alone comprising nearly 60%. While street litter is almost entirely composed of locally manufactured products (99%), the proportion of foreign-manufactured bottles on beaches increases sharply with remoteness, rising from under 5% at urban sites to over 40% at remote beaches.

Many foreign PET bottles are relatively young, indicating recent and open dumping from ships, primarily from China, whereas older, biofouled HDPE bottles indicate long-distance ocean drift from Southeast Asia. Despite relatively high national recycling rates for PET and HDPE, their dominance in beach litter highlights that recycling alone is insufficient to prevent environmental leakage. The differing composition of plastic items across environments highlights the need for both improved local waste management and stronger controls on marine-based sources of plastic pollution.
